title: webexercises test
description: A short description of the post.
contents:
What is used to make the vertical lines in the plot?


# echo = FALSE, results = 'asis'
opts <- c("install.package", 
            "install.packages", 
            answer = "library", 
            "libraries")

q1 <- mcq(opts)

cat("What function loads a package that is already on your computer?", q1)


What function loads a package that is already on your computer? install.packageinstall.packageslibrarylibraries

title: Blood feud: ggplot versus base R for beginers
description: ggplot2 is powerful, but what is its cognitive load for beginners?.
contents:
The data are on the abundance of elephants in a national park in Tanzania where poaching has dropped dramatically, and taken from Foley and Faust (2010), Table 1.
To plot the data in base R I need only
Three lines of code
One plotting function, plot()
One arguement, type = “b”



The syntax I’ve used is the same y = mx+b format folks learn in high school, and moreover is the same as that used for regression in R using the lm() function.
To plot the data in ggplot2 I need
7 lines of code
6 functions, including
data.frame() to turn my data into a dataframe
library() to call up
aes() to set up the x vs. y relationship
2 function to actually make the plot, geom_line() AND geom_point()




Moreover, the syntax doesn’t elicit the geometry of the relationship. Also, in this particular case ggplot is setting the increments of the x axis to non-sensical values of 1997.5 and 2002.5.






References
Foley and Faust 2010. Rapid population growth in an elephant Loxodonta africana population recovering from poaching in Tarangire National Park, Tanzania. Oryx 44:205 - 212. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0030605309990706

title: Welcome to Computational Biology for All!
description:
Welcome to our new blog, Computational Biology for All!. We hope you enjoy 
reading what we have to say!
contents:
Welcome to “Computational Biology for All.” This blog is dedicated to introducing quantitative methods to biologists. Topics will include:
computational biology
bioinformatics
phylogenetics
data science
statistical analysis
